Expectation1: Maintain regular communication with family members
Situation1: The grandmother learns that a family member is dealing with a significant personal crisis.
Expectation2: Officiate at life cycle events such as weddings, bar/bat mitzvahs, and funerals.
Situation2: A congregant has just passed away and the family needs him to officiate the funeral service very soon.
Story:
The phone trembled in my hand as I listened to my daughter’s voice, thick with tears. My grandson had been in an accident—nothing fatal, thank God, but serious enough to shake the whole family. As a grandmother, I felt the pull to rush to their side, to hold my daughter, to comfort my grandson, to be the steady presence they needed. I promised I would call back soon, my heart aching with worry.

No sooner had I hung up than my other phone rang. It was the son of Mrs. Goldstein, a beloved congregant. His mother had just passed away, and he was desperate for me to officiate the funeral. The family needed me, not just as their rabbi, but as a source of comfort and tradition in their grief. The funeral would have to be soon, as is our custom.

I stood in my kitchen, torn between two worlds. My family needed their grandmother. My congregation needed their rabbi. Both expected me to be present, to offer comfort, to lead. I felt the weight of both roles pressing down, each demanding my heart, my time, my presence.
